1. Flight Computer Modules¶

1.1. Main¶

1.2. File Manager¶

Logging, saving spectrometer samples If you need to save a file please use/call functions here

Basic file hierarchy for Oasis:

OASIS_SD_PATH/ (This is all on the SD card)
  • logs/

    • [All of our status logs] 0.statlog, 1.statlog, 2.statlog, 3.statlog…

  • samples/

    • [All of our spectrometer samples] file extension: .bin

    • Spectrometer samples are named using the UNIX timestamp they were taken at as well as the fractional amount of seconds (just pass in time.time(), don’t cast to an int)

  • debug/

    • [Any debug logs generated, probably unused]

OASIS_FLASH_PATH/ (This is all on the flash memory)

  • To be decided…

manifest.log format

Each line in manifest.log corresponds to the number of .dat file (For example, the first line corresponds to file 0.dat, second line corresponds to 1.dat, fourth line corresponds to 3.dat…)

Each line contains the UNIX timestamp that the sample was taken at

The order that samples occured in can be deduced through a combination of the file #, and the UNIX timestamp. This means that if two files have the same timestamp, the file with a lower file # was taken first.

class file_manager.FileManager(sd_path, flash_path)¶

This class manages all the spectrometer data files and log files

__init__(sd_path, flash_path)¶

Initialize self. See help(type(self)) for accurate signature.

get_last_two_samples()¶

Returns the two string of the last 2 spectrometer sample files.

Returns

This will be a 2x1 string array containing the data of the last two spectrometer sample files. The first string being the most recent followed by the second string being the second most recent

  • Array format: {[most recent file name].[file extension], [next recent file name].[file extension]}

  • If less than 2 files exist, then the second (and possibly the first) string will be left an empty string

Return type

list

get_latest_log_file()¶

Returns most recent log file.

Returns

log_file – A string of the file name for the most recent log file recorded.

Return type

str

list_all_logs()¶

Returns all log files in an array.

Returns

log_files – An array composed of every log file saved on Oasis’ sd card. The array will be in the format: {[most recent file], [next most recent file], …}

Return type

list

list_all_samples()¶

Returns strings of all spectrometer sample files.

Returns

sample_files – A nx1 string array of all n spectrometer files sorted from most recent to least recent. The array will be in the format: {[most recent file name].[file extension], [next recent file name].[file extension], …}

Return type

list

log_status(status_array, log_reason=0)¶

Append data into the log file. May automatically create a new file.

Parameters

  • status_array (list) – This is a byte array of status data

  • log_reason (int) – 0 = regular time log, 1 = command sent, 2 = new error, 3 = error resolved

Returns

number – 0 = success. Another number = failure to save file (for debugging purposes)

Return type

int

read_sample(timestamp)¶

Returns the data array of the specific file.

Parameters

time (str) – Specific file name for an array of spectrometer data at a certain time. This will be formatted as [name].[file extension]

Returns

data – A 2 by 3648 data array from the spectrometer (wavelength, intensity)

Return type

list

save_sample(timestamp, data)¶

After the spectrometer finishes sampling, it will send the data to this function to be saved.

Parameters

  • timestamp (str) – A string of current linux time to be formatted [timestamp].[file extension]

  • data (list) – A 2 by 3648 data array containing the recorded data from the spectrometer (wavelength, intensity)

1.3. Oasis Configuration¶

This module holds all global constants that may change frequently. This is meant to be a configuration file that any script can pull from. It is to be lightweight and contain only constants. (See 7. Oasis Constants)

1.4. Oasis Serial¶

Module for connecting to either physical serial lines or “virtual” serial lines (UDP sockets) for debugging. Handles low level reading of integers, strings, floats, files.

class oasis_serial.OasisSerial(serial_device, baud_rate=9600, debug_mode=False, debug_rx_port=0, debug_tx_port=0, rx_print_prefix=None)¶

Class that represents a serial connection. Passing debug_mode=True will cause this to open up a UDP server to receive debug serial data, and will write all serial data to a UDP port as well

When debug_mode is set to True, the program will attempt to connect to the UDP port provided by fake_serial.py. debug_rx_port will be the UDP port that we will listen to for incoming connections debug_tx_port will be the UDP port that we will connect to when sending bytes

__init__(serial_device, baud_rate=9600, debug_mode=False, debug_rx_port=0, debug_tx_port=0, rx_print_prefix=None)¶

When debug_mode is set to True, the program will attempt to connect to the UDP port provided by fake_serial.py. debug_rx_port will be the UDP port that we will listen to for incoming connections debug_tx_port will be the UDP port that we will connect to when sending bytes

in_waiting()¶

Return the number of characters currently in the input buffer

read_byte()¶

Returns a single byte read from the serial connection. Returns None if timed out reading the byte

Returns

b – The byte received from the serial connection

Return type

bytes

read_bytes(count)¶

Returns a bytearray of length count read from the serial connection and a boolean value saying whether or not the read timed out

Parameters

count (int) – A float to be sent over to the dummy rover

Returns

  • a (bytearray) – A byte array of bytes received from the serial connection

  • read_timeout (boolean) – A boolean representing whether the read timed out or not

read_float()¶

Returns a float read from the serial connection that was represented in our special ASCII encoded format

read_integer(size=4)¶

Returns a signed (positive or negative) integer read from the serial connection

Parameters

size (int) – The size of the integer (defaults to 4)

Returns

A signed integer from the bytes read

Return type

int

read_signed_integer(size=4)¶

Returns a signed (positive or negative) integer read from the serial connection

Parameters

size (int) – The size of the integer (defaults to 4)

Returns

A signed integer from the bytes read

Return type

int

read_unsigned_integer(size=4)¶

Returns an unsigned (positive only) integer read from the serial connection

Parameters

size (int) – The size of the integer (defaults to 4)

Returns

An unsigned integer from the bytes read

Return type

int

receive_file(fname='None')¶

Prepares to receive a file. Mainly used in dummy_rover.py

Parameters

fname (str) – The name of the file

send_bytes(b)¶

Sends bytes over to the dummy rover

Parameters

b (bytes) – Bytes to be sent over to the dummy rover

send_file(f, filename)¶

Transmits a file through serial, using error correction and packetization

Parameters

  • f (object) – A file object based on the filename

  • filename (str) – The name of the file being transmitted

Returns

A boolean representing whether or not the file was sent successfully

Return type

boolean

send_float(f)¶

This is our “ASCII encoded float” way of sending floats. This may be changed in the future.

Parameters

f (float) – A float to be sent over to the dummy rover

send_integer(i, size=4)¶

Sends a signed (positive or negative), big endian integer

Parameters

  • i (int) – A signed big endian integer

  • size (int) – The size of the integer (defaults to 4)

send_signed_integer(i, size=4)¶

Sends a signed (positive or negative), big endian integer

Parameters

  • i (int) – A signed big endian integer

  • size (int) – The size of the integer (defaults to 4)

send_string(s)¶

Sends an ASCII string

Parameters

s (str) – A string to be sent over to the dummy rover

send_unsigned_integer(i, size=4)¶

Sends an unsigned (positive only), big endian integer

Parameters

  • i (int) – An unsigned big endian integer

  • size (int) – The size of the integer (defaults to 4)

1.5. Read Log¶

This module is used in conjuction with our other modules to make a list of all log files.

read_log.get_log_files()¶

This method returns all log files as a list

Returns

l – This contains all log files

Return type

list

1.6. Repeated Timer¶

Taken from: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/474528/what-is-the-best-way-to-repeatedly-execute-a-function-every-x-seconds#474543 Allows for a timer to be set every _interval_ seconds to execute a function.

class repeated_timer.RepeatedTimer(interval, function, *args, **kwargs)¶

RepeatedTimer calls a function every _interval_ seconds until stop() is called.

__init__(interval, function, *args, **kwargs)¶

Initialize self. See help(type(self)) for accurate signature.

start()¶

Starts running _function_ every _interval_ seconds. Can be stopped with stop()

stop()¶

Stops running the timer. Can be started again with start()

1.7. Error Checking¶

Small module for ensuring that we can execute the requested command. This should really be refactored into the main code.

error_checking.is_valid_command(laser_status, spec_status, active_errors, cmd)¶

Checks if the command sent is a valid command

Parameters

  • laser_status (int) – This integer value contains the current status of the laser

  • spectrometer_status (int) – This integer value contains the current status of the spectrometer

  • active_errors (list) – This is a 21x1 boolean array containing all active errors

  • cmd (bytes) – This is the current command recieved from the rover

Returns

is_valid – Boolean of whether it’s a valid command

Return type

bool

Contains utility functions for debugging, and possibly commands to use during testing.

Attempts to automatically tune the PI loop.
